linkTarget.anchoringText: Fig.1 illustrates the estimation of incremental recoverable reserves through water injection optimization, defined as

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: Schematic diagram illustrating estimation of incremental reserves using water-drive performance curves.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Schematic diagram illustrating estimation of incremental reserves using water-drive performance curves.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The recovery characteristics of each reservoir are expressed by their different values of ER and therefore the fw-R curves are different from each other. In Tong’s Curve, ER is taken as the module, and a group of fw- R curves can be plotted on a normalized coordinate paper as shown in Fig. 2.

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: Tong’s Theoretical Curve, showing ultimate recovery factor for X Field inceasing from 36.5% to 40% due to water injection optimization.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Tong’s Theoretical Curve, showing ultimate recovery factor for X Field inceasing from 36.5% to 40% due to water injection optimization.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Case one. The sandstone reservoir in M Field consists of three flow units with average permeability varying from 50 mD to > 500 mD. Well A had been producing solely from the low-permeability top pay sand. By comparison, Well B produced from all the three pay sands (Fig. 3).

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: Schematic diagram showing commingled water injection to three sand units.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Schematic diagram showing commingled water injection to three sand units.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The rapid production decline in Well A was the response of pressure depletion. Based on the above analysis, the water injector was recompleted adopting a single-string adjustable eccentric water distributor. The technology enhanced water injection to the top flow unit while constraining injection to the lower two flow units. Both Well A and Well B responded to the injection adjustment immediately with a significant rise in production rates (Fig. 4). By May 2006, production rates of Well A and Well B had reached 566 BOPD and 725 BOPD, respectively, a significant increase from the pre-zonal water injection rates of 116 BOPD and 471 BOPD.

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: Production history curves illustrating production increases responding to zonal water injection: a. Well A performance; b. Well B performance.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Production history curves illustrating production increases responding to zonal water injection: a. Well A performance; b. Well B performance.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Case two. An inverted nine-spot well pattern produced oil from a multi-layer, low-medium permeability sandstone reservoir (Fig. 5). The heterogeneous reservoir is characterized by low permeability in the upper interval and medium permeability in the lower interval. Commingled water injection was performed during early stage pressure maintenance. Well B contained a STOIIP of 1.791 MMBO. With the water cut increasing from 35% to 60%, the production rate dropped sharply from 410 BOPD to 194 BOPD within one year (Fig. 6a).

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: Schematic diagram illustrating: a. inverted nine-spot pattern; b. commingled water injection resulting nonuniform injection between upper and lower intervals; and c. zonal water injection resulting in enhanced injection in the upper interval and reduced injection in the lower interval.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Schematic diagram illustrating: a. inverted nine-spot pattern; b. commingled water injection resulting nonuniform injection between upper and lower intervals; and c. zonal water injection resulting in enhanced injection in the upper interval and reduced injection in the lower interval.

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: commingled water injection resulting nonuniform injection between upper and lower intervals
zonal water injection resulting in enhanced injection in the upper interval and reduced injection in the lower interval.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Case two. An inverted nine-spot well pattern produced oil from a multi-layer, low-medium permeability sandstone reservoir (Fig. 5). The heterogeneous reservoir is characterized by low permeability in the upper interval and medium permeability in the lower interval. Commingled water injection was performed during early stage pressure maintenance. Well B contained a STOIIP of 1.791 MMBO. With the water cut increasing from 35% to 60%, the production rate dropped sharply from 410 BOPD to 194 BOPD within one year (Fig. 6a).

image-wrap.label: Figure 6

formatted-caption.caption-text: Well B production performance: a. oil rate and water cut vs. time; and b. water drive performance curve (Npvs. lgfw).

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: oil rate and water cut vs. time

linkTarget.anchoringText: A water injection optimization campaign was launched in 2009. The injection-production pattern was modified from line cutting to peripheral line injection, consisting of four producers and five injectors (Fig.7). The injection-production well spacing increased from 250 m to 450 m.
linkTarget.label: Figure 7

image-wrap.caption: Well location map showing change of water injection direction by converting well pattern from original line cutting (fig. 7a) to peripheral line (fig. 7b).

formatted-caption.caption-text: Well location map showing change of water injection direction by converting well pattern from original line cutting (fig. 7a) to peripheral line (fig. 7b).

linkTarget.anchoringText: The new well pattern led to change in water injection direction and helped expand sweep volume to further recover inter-well remaining oil and attic oil. The water injection optimization activity resulted in a significant increase in production rate from 110 BOPD to 194 BOPD and a slight drop of water cut from 97.9% to 96.7% (Fig. 8). Average production rate per well increased from 28 BOPD to 49 BOPD. Ultimate recovery factor increased by 10% from 58% to 68% (Wang, 2011).

image-wrap.label: Figure 8
image-wrap.caption: T Block SII11-12 Unit production performance showing significant oil rate increase and water cut drop resulting from modified well pattern.

formatted-caption.caption-text: T Block SII11-12 Unit production performance showing significant oil rate increase and water cut drop resulting from modified well pattern.

linkTarget.anchoringText: In the example shown in Fig.9, the distributary channel reservoir presents a great lateral permeability contrast between channel and inter-channel sands. Injected water mainly swept oil along high-permeability channel sand, causing the oil well in channel sandbody to have high water cut and low oil production. The injected water had been ineffectively cycling from injector to producer. Instead, the producers in the interchannel sand were bypassed. Water plugging workovers were implemented in Well Z4-7 and Well Z6-6 to optimize sweep efficiency.

image-wrap.label: Figure 9
image-wrap.caption: Facies map overlain with well production showing the production rise from wells in inter-channel sand after water plugging workovers (modified from Zhu, 2007).

formatted-caption.caption-text: Facies map overlain with well production showing the production rise from wells in inter-channel sand after water plugging workovers (modified from Zhu, 2007 ).

linkTarget.bib:
Zhu et al., 2007
L. H. Zhu , Q. L. Du , H. L. Liu , and W. F. Cao
2007.Remaining Oil Distribution Identification and Development Method, in Ji, B. Y., and Li, Y. X., eds. Multi-Discipline Study and Application in Daqing Oilfield. Beijing, China: Petroleum Industry Press.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The multi-layer, heterogeneous SII9-10 reservoir comprises seven sub-units. Among them, the two upper sub-units have low permeability of 160 mD and 290 mD, respectively; while the lower sub-units possess high permeability ranging from 1400 mD to 3500 mD (Fig. 10a). At the beginning of the study, the reservoir had recovered 32.2% STOIIP, was producing at 246 BOPD from 16 active producers with a water cut of 96.4%. Its ER was estimated as 36.3%. The significant permeability contrast between SII9 and SII10 results in substantial difference in recovery between the two reservoirs, which is 38.4% of STOIIP for the SII10 reservoir and 22.6% of STOIIP for the SII9 reservoir.
linkTarget.label: Figure 10

image-wrap.caption: Diagram showing: a. permeability contrast among sub-units of SII9-10 reservoir; b. well pattern of SII9 after injection-production unit subdivision; and c. well pattern of SII10 after injection-production unit subdivision (Modified from Wang, 2011).

formatted-caption.caption-text: Diagram showing: a. permeability contrast among sub-units of SII9-10 reservoir; b. well pattern of SII9 after injection-production unit subdivision; and c. well pattern of SII10 after injection-production unit subdivision (Modified from Wang, 2011 ).

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: permeability contrast among sub-units of SII9-10 reservoir
well pattern of SII9 after injection-production unit subdivision
well pattern of SII10 after injection-production unit subdivision

linkTarget.bib:
Wang, 2011
D. P. Wang
2011. Improved Oil Recovery Technology Advancement of Shengli Oilfield at Extra-High Water-cut Development Stage. Presented at the 2011 China Oil and Gas Development Congress held in Jinan, China , 15-17 November.

linkTarget.anchoringText: In SII10 reservoir unit, the injection-production spacings slightly expanded from 300/260 m to 380/300 m (Fig. 10c); while the voidage replacement ratio increased from 0.57 to 1.3. Production performance showed that within 10 months since the injection-production unit subdivision, the SII10 unit had its pressure restored from 1958 psi to 2161 psi, production rate rose from 187 BOPD to 223 BOPD and water cut reduced from 97% to 96.7% (Fig. 11). The SII10 was expected to achieve an incremental recovery by 9% STOIIP from 40% to 49% (Wang, 2011).

Cyclic water injection was adopted at a scheme of six-month half period. Within each individual cycle, water was injected into oil pay groups of SII, PIUpper in the first-half period with that of SIII, PILower suspended. Conversely, in the second-half period, water was injected into oil pay groups of SIII, PILower, with that of SII, PIUpper suspended (Fig. 12).

image-wrap.label: Figure 12
image-wrap.caption: Schematic diagram illustrating the cyclic water injection scheme in X Block.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Schematic diagram illustrating the cyclic water injection scheme in X Block.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The pilot cyclic water injection successfully alleviated oil rate decline and water cut rise (Fig. 13). Water cut dropped from 90.4% to a minimum of 88.4% and oil rate increased from 2111 BOPD to a maximum of 2160 BOPD in cyclic period one. Compared with the forecasted performances of conventional waterflooding through reservoir simulation, oil rate by cyclic water injection is generally higher than that by conventional water flooding. Estimated EURs by Type A water-drive performance curve indicate that cyclic water injection increased recoverable reserves by 1.84% from 51.7 MMBO to 52.7 MMBO.

image-wrap.label: Figure 13
image-wrap.caption: Production performances in response to cyclic water injection.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Production performances in response to cyclic water injection.
